Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Does Pheromone Evolution Drive Reproductive Compatibility in Dusky Salamanders? A Phylogenetic, Functional, and Behavioral Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The biological world is rich with sounds, smells, and movements that serve as communication signals, and demonstrate the evolution of life. Many species use specific signals to recognize mates, but signals and mate choice are evolutionarily dynamic. To date, few studies have examined the impact of signal similarities and differences on lineage diversification and adaptive radiations. This study incorporates molecular and behavioral techniques to test how reproductive isolation and speciation may have been influenced by the evolution of highly variable reproductive signals; courtship pheromones. The investigation will focus on dusky salamanders (genus Desmognathus), a group that displays dramatic differences in ecology, body size and life history and is known to have undergone a relatively recent adaptive radiation. The research specifically will test how convergence and introgression play a role in the geographic distributions of these pheromones, and if pheromone divergence is correlated with patterns of behavioral reproductive compatibility or isolation.

This study will develop molecular tools that can be used by other investigators, and provides a framework for the study of protein based mate recognition signals. This research will be disseminated through workshops at regional colleges and universities to provide further education on molecular biology, reproductive systems, and the evolution of communication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical communication through the use of pheromones is likely the most diverse and oldest mode of communication and is used across all taxa. Pheromones play diverse behavioral roles including alarm signals, territorial markings, and reproductive cues. For some groups of organisms, pheromone mediated communication is likely the most significant factor in species-specific recognition and mate choice.

Salamanders serve as model organisms for behavioral, ecological, and evolutionary studies; and represent an ideal system to study pheromone evolution due to their pervasive use in courtship. Male salamanders of many species exude courtship pheromones that function in attracting females and influence female receptivity. Analyses have shown species-specific variation in amino acid pheromone composition can result in complete behavioral reproductive isolation among populations/species. Therefore, courtship pheromones may have a fundamental role in reproductive compatibility and isolation, which can strongly influence species diversity.

Phylogenetic analyses have found that pheromone proteins have undergone incessant molecular evolution at the amino acid level, creating an assortment of highly variable proteins. Diversification of these pheromones appears to be the result of positive selection, with a high number of amino acid sites showing high rates of substitutions. Convergent and/or parallel amino acids substitutions and gene duplications are also commonly seen across the phylogeny of these pheromones.

To date, our knowledge of plethodontid courtship pheromone evolution is still very limited and based on few taxa. The purpose of this study was to further expand the number of species analyzed, and to address an additional group of plethodontids of which reproductive evolution has been studied for many years, the dusky salamanders. With the addition of more species, we can ascertain if pheromone evolution among plethodontid taxa is generalizable, and what may drive the evolution of these pheromone proteins across species.

During this project we collected representative specimens of all dusky salamander species to analyze the molecular evolution of the pheromone genes PMF and SPF. We have collected 167 sequences of PMF, from as many individuals representing 19 different species. For SPF we now have 305 sequences representing 92 individuals, and 19 different species. The reason for the disproportionate levels of sequences is because we discovered that SPF has undergone multiple duplications and increased sampling per individual was necessary to obtain maximum genetic diversity.

Overall, there appears to be no significant levels of selection across the PMF pheromone phylogeny, however, several amino acid sites appear to be under positive selection. There is also a high level of amino acid diversity reaching up to 34% divergence. For SPF we find multiple gene duplication events (>2 within all individuals), with one very old duplication seemingly present in all. Because of this, we get high levels of genetic diversity. We also see evidence of positive selection within this gene across Desmognathus. We also tested various metrics of reproductive isolation vs amino acid divergence between focal populations and found no significant correlation, however, of the amino acids predicted to be under positive selection, several of the sites do appear to show a correlation with reproductive isolation, suggesting that individual sites may be important for maintaining reproductive isolation
